THOMAS WEST. I am a mariner . I went home with Burrows; the prisoner slept in the room. I awoke about eight o'clock in the morning, and missed my jacket.

JOHN SWINGLAND
. I am a patrol. On the 2d of September, about half-past four o'clock in the morning, the prisoner passed me in Cannon-street - road, with something concealed under his jacket. I stopped him, and asked him what it was? he said it was a gown, and that a girl gave it to him instead of some money she had robbed him of. I found a pair of shoes in his pocket.
WILLIAM SUMMERS. I am a headborough. I found the prosecutor's jacket on the prisoner's back.
FRANCIS JACKSON. I searched the prisoner at the watch-house, and found a shawl in his hat, and five knives. He said they were his own.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found myself alone in the night and missed my waistcoat, which had 10s. in the pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1315.
CATHERINE ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , two copper medals, value 1d.; five shillings, two sixpences, and 81/2d. in copper money, the property of
Thomas Gordon
, from his person .

SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating them to be the property of
Lewis Levi
.

THOMAS GORDON
. I am the toll-collecter at Nine Elms
. On the 12th of August, between twelve and one o'clock at night, I was asleep in a chair in the toll-house; I was awoke, found the prisoner in custody, and my money gone out of my apron pocket. I knew nothing of her.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I am a patrol, and belong to Bow-street. On the 12th of August, between twelve and one o'clock in the morning, I was returning home to Little Chelsea, I saw the prisoner in company with a man, and listened to their conversation; she went towards the turnpike, before she got there she tried the gate of a house, but could not open it. She went to the toll-house, and said, "Halloo, tollman, have you got any porter?" He made no answer; she then went on. I passed her, stood at the corner, and heard her say, if you will give me two-pence I will get some porter, I have got the rest; they are up at the Princess of Wales, which is about two hundred yards off. Hearing no answer, I came back, and stood where I could see her and the prosecutor; she put her hand into his apron pocket, and took something out; she made use of a very indecent expression, and said, I shall go and get the porter, and immediately come to the door. I took her, and said she had been robbing the man; she said she had not. He awoke while I was struggling with her. I found five shillings, two sixpences, and 81/2d. in copper, an old halfpenny, and a pocket piece, in her hand. The man said he could swear to the old halfpenny, the pocket-piece, and a crooked halfpenny.

THOMAS GORDON
re-examined. I never saw the prisoner before. I can swear to three of the copper pieces, having had them sometime. I lost the monies stated in the indictment.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to Fulham to receive 8s., I saw Gordon at eight o'clock, very drunk, he gave me the crooked halfpence to get some porter, the publican would not take them; as I returned I went to the tollhouse, and tried to awoke him, as I came out I was taken.

JOHN MANSHIP. I am toll-collector at Kensington, and lodge opposite the turnpike-gate. I was standing at my door, and saw several things go by without paying; I also saw a man go into the toll-house afterwards; I told a gentleman I would go and see if there was any money, as the man might take it. I went in and awoke the prosecutor, I could only hear halfpence rattle in his apron, I could hear no silver rattle-this was at ten o'clock at night; he could not have taken 5s. from that time until one o'clock. Next morning he told me he had lost 5s. in copper; I said I had taken it over to my lodgings to take care of - He was very drunk.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1316.
ROBERT WHEELHOUSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , four casks, value 4s.; 250lbs. of butter, value 10l.; 53lbs. of honey, 2l.; and 26 hams, value 8l. the property of
Claus Frederick Huttman
.

CLAUS FREDERICK HUTTMAN. I am a dealer in provisions , and live in Great Prescot-street, Goodman's-fields. On the 31st of August, at night, my warehouse in the Tenter-ground was broken open, and the articles stated in the indictment taken out.

RICHARD PLUNKETT
. I am beadle of Whitechapel. On the 31st of August, about eleven o'clock at night the prosecutor came to the watch-house, I went with him to Chamber-street, Goodman's-fields; as soon as we got to the corner we heard the cry of watch; I immediately ran down the street, and saw the prisoner in custody of another man, who charged him with stealing the butter. I took him into the Red Lion, public-house, searched him, and found the key of a street-door on him, which the prosecutor said would open his warehouse. I took him to Lemon-street. I asked him where he lived, he said over the water, but he could not exactly say where; I asked where he slept the night before? he said on this side of the water. I put him in the watch-house. I got information of the property, and went to Duke's Head-court, Chamber-street, knocked at the door twice, a female asked who was there? I asked who lived there, she said Wheelhouse. I said I wanted to speak to her, as her brother was in trouble; she refused, saying she was in bed. I tried the key, it opened the door; I found his mother there, also two casks of butter, one of honey, and two sacks of hams, containing twenty-six, which I took to the watch-house.

WILLIAM HOLMES. I am a bootmaker, and live at No. 28, Chamber-street. I was standing at my door, and saw the prisoner coming towards me on the left-hand side, and three or four others on the right. I saw the prisoner speak to one man, who was loaded; one of them said to the prisoner go on; the prisoner crossed the street, and ran-each of them went on; the last man let a tub of butter fall, it struck me on my right arm. He went away, leaving it in the kennel. They were all loaded, except the prisoner. The landlord took the butter into my lodgings, and the prosecutor claimed it. I said I knew one of the party; the prisoner passed the door at the time, I said here is the man that I saw speak to the persons who were loaded. My landlord asked him if he knew any thing of the butter? he said No. I went for Plunkett, returned, and found the prisoner in the custody of my landlord. When I saw the prisoner run he went down Duke's Headcourt; I did not see the others go down the court. About an hour after I found the property there.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence When I went home my mother informed me a man had left the things there, and I was to meet him at a public-house; as I was going, I was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 37.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1317.
SAMUEL WILLIAMS
and
WILLIAM SAWYER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of September , one basket, value 1d., fourteen penny-pieces, and sixtyone halfpence , the monies of
George Sharpley
.

MARTHA SHARPLEY
. I am the wife of George Sharpley, we keep the White Horse, public-house, at Old Ford
. On the 3d of September, about half-past ten o'clock in the morning, the prisoner, Williams, came and asked me where Mr. Gordon lived; I said I did not know. Soon-after, I missed a basket containing 3s. and 81/2d. in copper, out of the drawer.

THOMAS ARNOLD. I am a cloth dresser. I saw the prisoners sitting against a wall, another boy came out of the White Horse with something in his blue apron; the prisoners got up and walked away with him. I went in to inform Mrs. Sharpley, she missed her halfpence, and I sent some men after the prisoners; they took them.

RICHARD DAVIS
. I pursued, and took Sawyer with a blue apron in his hand, which had the basket of copper in it.

BENJAMIN GOWER
. I took Williams.
SAWYEY'S Defence. I found the bundle in the road.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1218.
SAMUEL WEBB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , one shirt, value 6s., and one pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas State
.

THOMAS STATE. I am a hair-dresser , and live in Golden-lane, the prisoner was my servant . On the 15th of August, I saw him come out of my bed-room; I found my drawer open, and a shirt gone. He said he had not got it; I gave him in charge. The prisoner opened his tobacco-box, and asked me to take some; I found the duplicate of the shirt in it.
EDWARD FULLER. I am a pawnbroker. I took the shirt in pledge of the prisoner on the 15th of August.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 53.

Confined One Month , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1319.
ELIZA WIGGETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , one umbrella, value 5s.; one shawl, value 2s.; one pair of bellows, value 3s., and one handkerchief, value 2s. , the property of
Mary Johnson
, widow .

MARY JOHNSON. I keep a chandler's-shop at Somers'-town
. I took the prisoner into my service till the 10th of July, during which time I missed the articles stated in the indictment. She said she was engaged in Lord Brownlow's family.
WILLIAM NORRIS. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner at Hoxton, and found three duplicates of the property in her tea-chest, and the handkerchief on the shelf.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. She lent me the handkerchief.
GUILTY . Aged 51.
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1320.
WILLIAM WATERS
and
JOHN HURLOCK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , one saw, value 2s., the goods of
John Davis
; four saws, value 5s.; one chisel, value 6d.; one screw-driver, value 1s.; one hammer, value 2d., and one coat, value 6d. , the goods of
James Braine
.

JOHN DAVIS. I am a bedstead-maker , and lives at Leipzic Cottage, City-road
. On the 19th of July, about nine o'clock in the morning, I found my shop broken open, and the articles stated in the indictment gone.

GEORGE
JAMES BRAINE
. I am Mr. Davis's journeyman . I missed the things out of the shop.

THOMAS MAYHEW. I am a patrol of Bow-street. On the 19th of July, about a quarter after three o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners come from Leipzic Cottage, and walk down the City-road; one of them appeared bulky round the body. I secured Hurlock; the things fell from under his coat. Williams run away.

JOHN AVERY. I am a Bow-street officer., I was with Mayhew, and saw the prisoners come from the back of Leipzic Cottage, each had a great-coat on, and appeared bulky; Mayhew took Hurlock, and I took Waters-the saw fell from his back; he slipped his arms out of his coat, and ran off. I followed, and took him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
WATERS'S Defence. I saw Hurlock looking at the things; he asked me to carry the coat and saw for him.
HURLOCKS'S Defence. I found them among some rubbish.

WATERS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

HURLOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1321.
JOHN WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , one copper boiler, value 5s. , the goods of
William Allen
.

WILLIAM ALLEN. I keep the Portland Arms, public-house, in Upper Berkley-street
. On the 30th of July, about a quarter before ten o'clock at night, I missed the copper boiler out of my kitchen.

WILLIAM RUSSELL
. I am a watchman. I was at the corner of Upper Berkley-street, about a quarter before ten o'clock at night, the prisoner passed me with a basket. I heard the alarm, and ran after him; he threw the basket down. I picked it up, and found the boiler in it.

BENJAMIN RUSSEL
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner come out of the prosecutor's house with the basket in his hand; I ran after him, he threw it down. I secured him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of it.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1322.
JOHN VICKERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , fifty-one knives, value 6s., and one spoon, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Alto
.

THOMAS ALTO
. I keep the Rose, public-house, in Frog-lane, Islington
. On the 15th of July, the prisoner came and had a pint of beer at my house; he left, and returned in about a quarter of an hour with a woman, he had some more and went away. In about half an hour I missed the knives. I went out, and overtook him with two women; he had the knives tied up in his neck-handkerchief. I gave him in charge.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The women gave them to me to carry.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1323.
SOPHIA STANLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , one tea-caddy, value 5s., and one tabacco-box, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Beeley
.

THOMAS BEELEY. I am a cutler , and live in Red Lion-street, Holborn
. On the 1st of September, my servant called me up; I missed the tea-caddy. I sent my boy out, he brought the prisoner back with it; my tobacco-box was in it.
WILLIAM MILLER. I am the prosecutor's servant. I went after the prisoner, and overtook her in Dean-street with the caddy in her apron.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A woman brought it out, and gave it to me carry.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1324.
THOMAS RANGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , one wheelbarrow, value 18s. , the goods of
Thomas Chapman
.
THOMAS CHAPMAN. I am a carpenter , and live in Philip-street, Kingsland-road. My lodger lent the prisoner my wheelbarrow, he was to return it in half an hour. He never brought it back.

ELIZA SABIN
. I lent the prisoner the wheelbarrow in July to bring me two sacks of saw-dust, he promised to return it in half an hour. He never did.

ALEXANDER ATKINSON
. I am a broker. The prisoner sold me the barrow for 6s.; he said the woman sent him to sell it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I meant to buy it of him again.
GUILTY . Aged 63.
Confined One Year .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1325.
JOHN READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , one jacket, value 9s., and one pair of trowsers, value 7s. , the goods of
John Treisler King
.

JOHN TREISLER KING. I am a tailor , and live at Shoreditch
. On the 30th of June, at a quarter before nine o'clock in the morning, my neighbour alarmed me, I ran out and brought the prisoner back; I found nothing on him. The jacket hung in the shop, the strings were cut to get it away.

PHILIP LOVEGROVE
. I keep the Fountain, public-house, opposite the prosecutor's. On the 30th of June, about a quarter before nine o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner and another man pass the prosecutor's door about three yards, and look to see if any body was in the shop; they then returned-the prisoner laid hold of the dress, tore it down with great violence, and gave it to the other man, who put it under his Guernsey-frock; both ran away together. I run over and alarmed the prosecutor, who pursued and brought the prisoner back; the other got away. I am sure the prisoner is the man.
Prisoner's Defence. I was taken, but know nothing of it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1326.
SAMUEL POULSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , one coat, value 5s., and one pelisse, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Morris
.

THOMAS MORRIS. I live in Judd-place, Somers'-town
, the prisoner lodged with me. I lost a coat and pelisse, and found them at the pawnbroker's. I believe the prisoner was in great distress.
WILLIAM LACK. I am apprentice to Mr. Drew, who is a pawnbroker. The prisoner pledged the pelisse with me.
CHARLES BALIS. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pledged a coat with me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1327.
TIMOTHY MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 12 bottles, value 3s.; 10 quarts of wine, value 54s., and one basket, value 10s. , the goods of
Christopher Burrows
and
Richard Hodgson
.

MR. RICHARD HODGSON. I am in partnership with Christopher Burrows, we live in Little Eastcheap. On the 8th of August the prisoner called at our house, about five o'clock in the afternoon, desired me to send half a dozon of wine so the Strand. I said we did not sell less than a dozen - He then ordered a dozen, and said he would send the money by the porter. I asked him his name? he said it did not signify. I gave Haines (my porter), the wine to take with him, and told him not to deliver it without the money-he returned without either the wine or the money.

THOMAS HAINES
. I am the prosecutor's porter. I went to carry the wine with the prisoner. When we got to Devereux-court, he said I must not go into the house, as he was a dealer in wine, and they would ask me where I brought it from. He took it from me with the basket, and went into the Sun public-house. He gave me 6d., told me to get a pint of beer, and wait five or ten minutes, and he would bring me the money, bottles, and basket - He never returned. I waited a long time, and then wentinto the house - He was gone. I found there was a passage through the house into Essex-street. I heard nothing of him till the 13th of August, when he was taken. I would not have delivered the wine without the money, if I had known he meant to take it away. I am certain he did not come out of the front door.
CHARLES BROWN. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 13th of August.
Prisoner's Defence. I told him to wait - I came to the place in about half an hour, but he was gone. I fell into bad company, and spent the money.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1328.
THOMAS MABBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , one tea-caddy, value 1s. 9d.; one reel and spindle, value 2s.; one mouse-trap. value 1s.; one brush, value 1s.; two pair of snuffers, value 3s., and two hammers, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Freer
.

CHARLES WILLIAMS
. I am a constable of Hammersmith. On the 25th of August I searched the prisoner's apartments, and found the articles stated in the indictment there-the prisoner was not there. Some of them were found in his bed-room, and the remainder in a cupboard. I found two hammers and a reel in the cellar. Next morning I took him; he said he was in want.

THOMAS FREER. I am an ironmonger , and live at Hammersmith, the prisoner was my servant. On the 25th of August I had his apartments searched - He had left me the day before. The things which were found are mine.
Cross-examined by MR. WALFORD. Q. Did not your apprentice run away - A. No, I turned him away.

JAMES DIGBY
. The prisoner lodged with me. He worked in the cellar, where the things were found.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the reel as old iron-my master lent me the other things to use in my business. I used to work for him in my cellar.

JAMES DIGBY
re-examined. There was a fight between the prisoner and prosecutor about his not paying him his wages. He had got the prisoner's things in his place. I went to the prosecutor, and told him the prisoner was innocent. He said, "Never mind-if he gets over this I will have him another way."

MR. ANDREWS. Q. Are you related to the prisoner - A. No. I was outside with the mob, when the prisoner and prosecutor were fighting. The prisoner's wife called out Murder! and two or three rushed into the house.

THOMAS FREER
re-examined. Q. Did you fight with the prisoner - A. No. There was a scuffle - He said he would murder me for charging him with the robbery. He made his escape out of window.

EDWARD EDGSON
. I am a constable. Mr. Freer sent for me in the evening. The prisoner had escaped out of the window. Mr. Freer told me to take him for making a disturbance in his house. I do not think he said he had stolen any thing.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1329.
SAMUEL MACEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , one handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Battie
, from his person .

JOHN BATTIE
. On the 22d of July I was at Sadler's Wells theatre
, towards the end of the play. I lost my handkerchief, and 1l. 5s. out of my pocket. I heard some person had been taken up, went to the office, and found the prisoner in custody. The officer produced my handkerchief to me as soon as I missed it.

WILLIAM WAINWRIGHT
. I am an officer. I was in the pit of the theatre, it being a benefit night, and saw the prisoner, and several others in his company, feeling people's pockets. Some person intimated that he suspected the prisoner. I laid hold of him, searched him, and found a handkerchief concealed in his breeches, and one which the prosecutor claimed, in his hat. He said they were both his own, and that he bought the one found in his hat in Liquorpond-street of a boy for 2s., just before he came to the theatre that evening. I put him in the watchhouse. I saw the prosecutor that evening, and showed him both the handkerchiefs and my own-he selected his own from them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up in the pit.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1330.
ELIZA MULLENDER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , two hats, value 8s.; one shawl, value 2s.; one petticoat, value 6d.; one shirt, value 2s.; one frock, value 18d., and one piece of patch work, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Atkins
.

MARY ATKINS
. I am the wife of
Samuel Atkins
, who lives in Willow-walk
, the prisoner used to bring her work and sit with me. On the 15th of June she came to my house to take care of my children while I was in Clerkenwell prison for debt. I came home and missed the articles stated in the indictment,

LAUNCELOT WILD
. I am servant to Mr. Walker, who is a pawnbroker. On the 15th of June the prisoner pledged a piece of patchwork with me for 18d. - she said she pledged it for Atkins.

GEORGE WILLIAM KNIGHT
DURHAM. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Hollywell-lane. I have two hats and a shirt pledged with me in the name of Atkins.
JOHN FORRESTER. I took the prisoner in charge. The prosecutrix gave me the duplicates.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was taking care of her house. There was no money to buy her children any victuals. Her husband told me to pledge them to feed the children. She was not in prison for debt.
MARY ATKINS re-examined. I was in prison for an assault.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1331.
THOMAS M'DERMOT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , two shirts, value 1l. 8s.; one razor, value 2s.; one strap, value 2s.; two pair of stockings, value 6s.; one pair of gaiters, value 5s.; one button-stick, value 3d.; three brushes, value 3s.; two pair of gloves, value 4s.; one knife, value 2d.; two neck handkerchiefs, value 3s., andone pair of gaiters, value 1s. 6d. , the property of
George Nowell
.

GEORGE NOWELL
. I belong to the First Regiment of Guards , and lodge at the Duke's Head, public-house, in Reeves's-mews, South Audley-street
. On the 29th of August, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I lost my box containing the articles stated in the indictment out of the garret - They were safe at eight o'clock. The prisoner afterwards came into the house; I followed him, and charged him with it. He had been about the house all the afternoon. On the Wednesday following I found my things in possession of Hampton.

HENRY HAMPTON
. I am a dealer in marine stores, and live in Swallow-street. The prisoner sold me the knife, fork, razor, and two pair of stockings. He said he was out of place, and they were things he used to travel with. I knew him before.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 30.

Confined One Year , and
Publicly Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1332.
REBECCA MALLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , one silver watch, value 30s.; two watch keys, value 2s.; one piece of foreign coin, value 3d.; one pair of trowsers, value 10s. 6d.; and one pair of shoes, value 10s., the goods of
John Passmore
; one pair of trowsers, value 10s. 6d.; one pair of stockings, value 2s. 6d., and one pair of shoes, value 10s. , the goods of
William Hall
.

JOHN PASSMORE. I am in the LifeGuards . On the 31st of July, Hall and I fell in with the prisoner at seven o'clock in the evening, at Paddington, and went with her and another girl to Ivy-court, St. Giles's
. Between four and five o'clock next morning we missed the prisoner and our property. We were intoxicated.

WILLIAM HALL
. I was with Passmore. I also missed my things.

Prisoner's Defence. They were both intoxicated, and gave me the watch; they behaved improperly to me, and left the room.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1333.
JOHN BELL BRODERICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , one watch, value 30s.; one seal, value 1s., and one key, value 1d. , the property of
Thomas Brooksbank
.

THOMAS BROOKSBANK. I am a sailor . On the 31st of August I lost my watch out of the Reward brig, which laid off Hermitage tier
. The prisoner was an acquaintance; he saw me put it in the trunk, which was in the forecastle. I left him there, returned in about an hour, and missed it.

JOHN SPENCER
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 31st of August the prisoner pledged the watch with me.

WILLIAM HUTCHINS
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the ribbon and seal upon him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1334.
SAMUEL BAMFIELD
and
JOHN SHEEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , two pair of sheets, value 1l. 10s. the goods of
James Henry Leigh
.

ANN HIGHAM
. I am housemaid to Mr.
James Henry
Leigh, who lives in Portman-square
. On the 25th of July, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoners in the kitchen-passage, which communicates with the area. They were dressed like sweeps, and had a black sack with them. They ran away when they saw me, leaving the sack on the area steps. I pursued, but lost sight of them. A soldier stopped them. I found two pair of my master's sheets in the sack, which I had put in the housekeeper's room just before.

WILLIAM POTTER
. I am a corporal in the Guards. I went in pursuit of the prisoners, and saw them at the corner of Portman-street, just by the prosecutor's house. They ran up Bryanston-street. I stopped Bamfield in the Park, he got through some broken rails there; I told him he was my prisoner, and must go with me; he said he would not; I found a pair of silk stockings on him, and took him back. Higham said they were the two. I never lost sight of them.

WILLIAM MASON
. I am a servant in Chapel-court, King-street, I saw Potter pursuing the prisoners. I took Sheen in Seymour-place. He threw a latch key away. Higham said he was one of them.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
BAMFIELD'S Defence. I found the stockings in the Park.
SHEEN'S Defence. I saw him find them.

BAMFIELD -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SHEEN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1335.
LYDIA HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 20s. in copper monies numbered , the property of
William Luff
, the elder.

WILLIAM LUFF, SEN. I keep the Fountain public-house, in King-street, Seven-Dials
. The prisoner lodged with me, on the same floor as my bed-room. On the 2d of September, about half past nine at o'clock night, my children went up to bed. Suspecting the prisoner, I watched her, and saw her leave her room and go into my bed-room, where my money was. She had no business there. My little girl came down and went up again, I followed her half way up the stairs, and my little boy gave me some information. I had told him to watch; I then went into my room, and missed two papers of halfpence which had been safe half an hour before. I immediately went into the prisoner's room, and told her I was sorry to accuse her, but I missed two 5s. papers of copper, and nobody but her and my children had been in the room. She strongly denied it. I said I would send for an officer. She then gave me 10s. worth, and said my son gave them to her. She said she had two more papers, which her husband had given her. He was sitting in the room. He told her she must have spent all the money he gave her. I asked her to show them to me, which she did. I told her I could swear to them, and that she had taken all four that evening. I had marked them with a cross. She then said my niece gave them to her.
ELIZA HAYES. I live with my uncle. I never gave the prisoner any paper of halfpence.

WILLIAM LUFF
, JUN. I am the prosecutor's son. When I went to bed, the prisoner came into the room. I never gave her any halfpence.

WILLIAM LUFF
, SEN. re-examined. I can swear to the four papers by my mark. I missed four.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1336.
JOHN LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , one pair of trowsers, value 10s. the goods of
Edward Willis
.

SARAH WILLIS
. I am the wife of Edward Willis, a salesman . On the 6th of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, the trowsers hung at the door. I met the prisoner at the shop-door, and asked him what he wanted; he made no answer, but went away. He appeared bulky. I followed him, stopped him, and took the trowsers out of his bosom.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 33.

Confined Three Months , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1337.
JOHN JONES
and
JAMES CROUCH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , two live pigs, price 3l. the property of
Charles Prendergast
.

CHARLES PRENDERGAST
. I am a labourer , and live in Church-lane, St. Giles's
. I had two pigs which I kept in my back-yard. The street door is kept open. On Sunday morning I missed them. They were black and white.

BRIDGET PRENDERGAST
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I saw the pigs safe at seven o'clock at night, and fastened the yard-door. Next morning I missed them. The prisoners are strangers.

MARY ANN
MAHONY. I lodge opposite the prosecutor. I saw the prisoners and another boy standing at the corner of Church-lane, about one o'clock in the morning; when they saw me, they went away. I was attending a sick person. Between two and three o'clock I saw them again. Jones went into the prosecutor's passage, the door was open; I saw the pigs come out, he let them out of the yard. Crouch and the other man waited at the door, Jones and the other man each carried a pig, Crouch went away with them. I called out "Stop those young men with the pigs." I was at the door at the time; I had gone out to get some cloves. The watchman was at the top of the street, he did not hear me. I saw the prisoners next day at Marlborough-street.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS. I am a patrol of St. Giles's. At four o'clock in the morning I saw the prisoners and another man going up High-street, with two black and white pigs. I knew them before, and did not stop them. On Sunday night I saw Crouch and took him into custody. I asked him if he hurt himself much with the pigs; he said no, not much. I had seen him fall, and the other fell over him, He said he only drove the pigs out for a bit of lark, and he did not know what became of them.
JONES. Q. Did you not ask me to take the pigs to the Green-yard - A. No.

WILLIAM PRINCE
. I am a watchman. On Sunday morning, about ten minutes past four o'clock, I saw the prisoners, and another man dressed like a butcher, driving two pigs. The prisoners went after the pigs, as they went a contrary way. Jones ran against Crouch and pushed him down, as he ran after the pigs. I went up and asked what was the matter; Jones said the pigs had broken out of a pound; that Crouch knew the owner, and was driving them home. Crouch made no answer; he appeared hurt. I did not suspect him. The pigs were black and white. I saw Jones in Dyot-street, at ten o'clock that night, and took him. He denied the charge.
CROUCH'S Defence. I never saw them.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

CROUCH-
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Confined Two Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1338.
ROBERT HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of December , one trunk, value 10s. the goods of
Thomas Lane
and
Alexander Billing
.

THOMAS CHARLES HORNBLOW
. I am shopman to Thomas Lane and Alexander Billing, who are trunk-makers
, and live in the Strand
. On the 11th of December, about ten o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner with the trunk on his shoulder, which he took from the door. I pursued, secured him with it, and took him to the watchhouse.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress.
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1339.
JOHN HIGGINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , one pair of trowsers, value 6s. , the goods of
William Stokes
.

MARY STOKES
. I am the wife of
William Stokes
, who is a Custom-house Officer . On the 26th of June his trowsers were hanging in the garret to dry. I saw the prisoner come down stairs with them under his arm. I ran after him, but lost him. I am certain he is the man.

JOSEPH CHAPMAN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in St. John-street. On the 26th of June the prisoner pledged the trowsers with me for 3s.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A sailor sent me to sell them.
GUILTY . Aged 60.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1340.
JANE HOPKINS
and
BENJAMIN HASWELL
were indicted, for
stealing, on the 25th of August , one rule, value 1s.; four half-crowns, and 23/4d. in copper monies numbered, the property of
Michael Corbet
, from his person .

MICHAEL CORBET. I am a stone-mason , and live in Somers'-town. On the 25th of August, about twelve o'clock at night, I met the prisoner Hopkins, and went to Lascelle's-court, St. Giles's
, with her. As soon as I got into the room she put her hand into my pocket, took my moneyout, and ran off with it. The prisoner Haswell and three others were in the room at the time. There was no light, and I was afraid to make any noise. As soon as it was daylight he took me down stairs, and told me to go away. I asked him for my rule, he went up stairs, returned, and said it was not there. I saw it in his bosom, and went for a watchman; he followed, and gave it to me. I gave him in charge. I found Hopkins under the bed, and gave her in charge also. I was not with her a moment.
COURT. You told the magistrate you were with her half an hour - A. I was not.
WILLIAM PRICE. I am a watchman. The prosecutor fetched me, and gave the prisoners in charge. I found the rale on Haswell. I found no money on either of them.
HOPKINS'S Defence. He was intoxicated, and gave me nothing.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1341.
CHARLES HENSLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , one chaise-harness, value 1l. 10s., and one saddle, value 5s. , the goods of
James Fisher
, Esq.

STEPHEN MORRIS
. I am servant to James Fisher, Esq. who is chief clerk at the Auditing Office, in the Exchequer. The harness was under my care. On the 6th of August, about half-past nine o'clock, I locked it up in the stable, in Dean's-yard
. Next morning, at six o'clock, I found it broken open, and the property stolen.

EPHRAIM WILSON
. I am a patrol. On the 7th of August, in the morning, I was in Orchard-street, and saw the prisoner and two more come out of Dean's-yard, with something on their backs, and going towards the end of Queen Ann-street; I crossed, and waited for them; the prisoner came down to me, I collared him immediately. He asked me what I wanted, and let his sack fall on my hand, which broke my hold; he ran up the street, I followed, several watchmen tried to stop him, but he passed them, I overtook him in Duck-lane, the watchman had stopped him. I am sure he is the man. I never lost sight of him. He wanted to fight the watchman. The others got away.

WILLIAM GOODENOUGH
. I saw the prisoner drop the bag; I struck at him, he got off, and threw it down-it contained the harness and other things - He threw away four picklock keys, eight skeleton keys, and a phosphorus box. I am sure he is the man.

HENRY COOKMAN. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner, and two other men come into the street, Walton stopped him - He got off, and threw the property down. I took the bag to the watch-house, it contained the property stated in the indictment. I am certain he is the man.
DANIEL BEAKLEY. I am a watchman. I stopped the prisoner; as he ran he struck me on the head.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the bag.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1342.
WILLIAM BELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , one jacket, value 10s. , the goods of
Christiana Kemp
.

CHRISTIANA KEMP. I live at Shadwell
. On the 21st of July, about dusk, I saw the prisoner go up stairs and come down, he lodged in the house. I went up, and missed the jacket; I came down and charged him with it - He denied it.
JOHN BROWN. I took the prisoner in charge; he took me behind the copper, and showed me the jacket in a bundle.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1343.
THOMAS GOWER
and
FRANCIS BRUCE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , one handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a certain person unknown, from his person .

SAMUEL LACK
. I am a smith, and live in Russell-street, Covent Garden. On the 12th of July, between twelve and one o'clock in the day, I saw the prisoner in company with another man following a gentleman through Russell-street
. I was at my window, up two-pair of stairs; I saw Gower take the handkerchief from the gentleman's pocket and throw it to Bruce, who tucked it into his waistcoat. I ran down, went out, and found them with the other man in Drury-lane. I took the prisoners into custody; the other man got away. I found the handkerchief in Bruce's waistcoat; I found another in Bruce's hat, and two others in his pocket. Somebody on the opposite side called to them to resist.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. They were on the opposite side to me.
GOWER'S Defence. The handkerchief is my father's.

GOWER -
GUILTY Aged 17.

BRUCE -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Two Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1344.
ESTHER GILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , one sheet, value 7s. , the goods of
Sarah Dyer
.

SARAH DYER. I keep the Crown and Sceptre, public-house, at Brompton
; the prisoner lodged five weeks with me. I lost a sheet, and suspected her; I had her apprehended, and found it at the pawnbroker's.

JANE GLADHILL
. I live at Knightsbridge; the prisoner brought the sheet to me, she said it belonged to a poor woman, and asked me to sell it for her. I sold it to Denford for 7s. 6d.

MARGARET DENFORD
. I bought the sheet of Gladhill.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY Aged 41.
Confined Six Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1345.
ALEXANDER FLEMMING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , one table-cloth, value 2s., and 11s. in copper monies, numbered , the property of
Thomas Hale
.

THOMAS HALE. I keep an eating-house in Wentworth-street, Whitechapel
, the prisoner was my servant ; he came to me the beginning of June. On the 28th, I put a box, containing the money, on the shelf. Next morning, when I went to call him, I found he had absconded; I found the back-door unbolted, 11s. in copper, and a table-cloth gone. On the 11th of August, he was brought to me, and said he took them.

RICHARD PLUNKETT
. I am an officer. On the 11th of August, the prisoner was given into my charge by his father. He said he took the copper and table-cloth which he had sold, and spent the money.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about it, my father lodged in the same house.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1346.
WILLIAM EDWARDS
was indicted for
embezzlement .
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1347.
WILLIAM DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , one sheet, value 7s.; four handkerchiefs, value 2s.; three shirts, value 7s.; three pair of stockings, value 4s., and one apron, value 1s. , the goods of
Richard Rawley
.

RICHARD RAWLEY I am a baker , and live in George-street, Spitalfields
. On the 24th of June, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning, my child alarmed me, and said there was a man in the first-floor room, I ran up; when I got to the top of the stairs, my street - door was opened, and a person said a man had ran out of my private door with a bundle of linen. I ran out, but lost sight of the person. I sent for an officer, the people said the prisoner was up a passage in the street - we were examining the house, and heard a noise in the street; the officer ran out and took the prisoner. I found my room-door open, and the articles stated in the indictment gone.

THOMAS REYNOLDS
. I am a cheesemonger. I heard of the robbery. I watched outside while Hardy, the constable, searched a house three doors from the prosecutor's. I saw the prisoner come out of another door of the prosecutor's house in Thrall-street, I pursued, and stopped him in Fashion-street, and found the sheet tied round his body, and the rest of the things in a bundle.

THOMAS HARDY
. I am a constable. I was searching a house, I heard he had run from another door; I saw him running, and secured him in Fashion-street. I found the bundle on him. He said he broke the door open and took the things out of the room; that he lived by thieving, and if he had his liberty to-morrow, he would thieve again.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I hope I shall be sent abroad for life.
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1348.
SARAH CULLUM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , five sheets, value 12s.; two shirts, value 2s.; two aprons, value 1s.; one umbrella, value 6d.; one table-cloth, value 1s.; one waistcoat, value 1s.; two shifts, value 3s.; one frock, value 1s.; one bed curtain, value 3s.; three handkerchiefs, value 3s.; one shawl, value 1s.; one pair of boots, value 1s., and one napkin, value 1s. , the property of
Philip Elias
.

ESTHER ELIAS
. I am the wife of
Philip Elias
, who is a furrier , and lives in Bell-lane, Spitalfields
. I buy and sell old clothes in the street; the prisoner had lived servant with me about a year and a half; I missed things several times, and asked her about them; she said she knew nothing about them. I examined my drawers, and missed these things; I asked her about them, she said they were being mangled. I had got my things from the mangler's the Friday before. I told her to fetch them; she returned, saying, I should have them in half an hour. I went to the mangler's; in consequence of what I heard I examined, and missed all the property stated in the indictment. I got an officer, and the prisoner gave me about sixteen duplicates, I told her she had more; she then gave me a purse containing thirty-three, eight of which were her own, the rest related to my property, by which means I found it. She said she spent the money in gin.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am servant to Mr. Pearl, who is a pawnbroker, and lives in Whitechapel. I have an apron, a sheet, a shift, a frock, a table-cloth, a waistcoat, and a curtain, pledged with me by the prisoner. The duplicates found on her are our's.

JAMES HAVEL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have twelve articles pledged with me by the prisoner.

WILLIAM FLETCHER
. I have two articles pledged with me by the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I intended to redeem them.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1349.
WILLIAM COOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on 13th of June , one bridle, value 1l. 10s. , the property of
Francis Rougemont
.

SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating it to be the property of
Abraham de Fontaine
.
The witnesses not appearing, the prisoner was
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1350.
WILLIAM BENTLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , one pair of shoes, value 3s. , the property of
William Thomas Wilkins
.

WILLIAM
THOMAS WILKINS
. I am a salesman , and live in Oxford-street
. On the 25th of June I saw the prisoner come to my door, and take a pair of shoes down; as he was taking another pair I seized him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress; and had nothing to eat for two days.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1351.
JAMES BIRD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , one pair of breeches, value 10s., and one waistcoat, value 2s. , the property of
James Bayley
.

JAMES BAYLEY. I am a butcher , and live at Mr. King's, in Union-street, Oxford-market
. On the 25th of July the prisoner slept with me; I got up at seven o'clock the next morning, and left him in bed, I went up soon after, found him gone, and my waistcoat and breeches.

WILLIAM KING
. I keep the house. The prisoner came down and went out in the morning, without going into the tap-room.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1352.
CATHERINE BURNS
and
ELEANOR BRYAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , one quilt, value 3s., and one sheet, value 2s. , the goods of
Samuel Burfield
.

SUSAN BURFIELD
. I am the wife of Samuel Burfield, who is a carpenter , and lives in Barton-lane, near Princes-square
. On the 16th of August I was ill in bed, the prisoners came to see me, and went up to my first-floor room, to look at it, I told them not to go, but they took the key and went; the quilt and sheet were there; they returned in about ten minutes, and put the key in its place, they then went out to get some cloves, and never returned. I missed the things out of the room-nobody but them had been there.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1353.
JOSEPH POTTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of May , one wheelbarrow, value 5s. , the property of
Robert Askew
.

SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating it to be the property of the
inhabitants and parishioners of the parish of St. George
.

THIRD COUNT, the same, only stating it to be the goods of the
overseers of the poor of the said parish
for the time being.

ROBERT ASKEW
. On the 16th of May I was employed by the parish of St. George to repair the streets - I had seven wheelbarrows under my care-about two o'clock, as I returned from dinner, I missed one.
JOHN DURRANT. I am a coal-dealer, and live in Mercer-row, Shadwell. I bought the wheelbarrow of the prisoner; he said it was his father's.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
FRANCIS JACKSON. I am a constable. I took the prisoner in charge. He said it was distress that drove him to do it. He appeared distressed.
Prisoner. I am sorry for it.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1354.
JAMES ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , one jacket, value 10s.; one waistcoat, value 4s.; one pair of trowsers, value 10s.; one hat, value 5s., and one pair of stockings, value 2s. , the goods of
George Riddle
.
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1355.
THOMAS FERDINAND THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , two pair of trowsers, value 15s. , the goods of
Martin Lenans
.
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1356.
RICHARD RICHARDSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , one handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Stephen Bossy
, from his person .

STEPHEN BOSSY. I live in Lower Thames-street. On the 14th of September, between eight and nine o'clock at night, I was in Finsbury-square
, and felt my handkerchief going from my pocket. I turned round, and saw the prisoner, with three others much older than himself. I saw the prisoner drop my handkerchief - I immediately seized him, and said I would take him to the watch-house-the other three immediately made off. He resisted very violently, and said I should not take him, as I was not an officer - He denied the charge. Vann immediately told him he had been watching him, and he would take him, which he did.
THOMAS VANN. I am constable of the night. I took the prisoner in charge. I found a handkerchief on him, marked T.S. - he said it was his own.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Several boys were behind him. I saw one of them take it, and throw it down.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1357.
ANN NEWTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , three half-crowns, the monies of
George Sayer
, from his person .
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1358.
GEORGE MASON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , one picture, value 5s., and three pieces of carpet, value 5s. , the goods of
William Boadman
.

WILLIAM BOADMAN. I am a tobacconist , and live at Wapping. On the 5th of August I left my pictures and carpet at Hucks's. I never authorized the prisoner to call for them. The painting was a chesnut cart-house.

JAMES HUCKS
. I keep the Anchor and Hope, public-house, at Shadwell-these things were landed at my house for the prosecutor; the prisoner was in the prosecutor's company at the time, and Boadman was hiring him to take them to his house. I told the prosecutor he might leave them at my house, which he did. Between five and six o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came again, and said he was sent for them - I delivered them to him.

GEORGE WILLIAM KNIGHT
DURHAM. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Holywell-lane. On the 6th of August the prisoner pledged three pieces of carpet with me he afterwards redeemed them.

SAMUEL JAMES
WOOLLAT. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Oxford-street. On the 6th of August the prisoner soldme the painting of a chesnut cart-horse for 6s. - I sold it again.
Prisoner's Defence. I understood I was to fetch them. I afterwards got drunk and sold them.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1359.
JOHN LAKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July . 1lb. of butter, value 1s., and 1lb. of mutton, value 6d. , the goods of
Robert Anderson
, Esq.

MARY FREEMAN
. I am servant to
Robert Anderson
, Esq., who lives in York-buildings, New-road
. On the 19th of July, about five o'clock in the morning, I missed the mutton and butter out of the area cupboard-it was not locked.

JOHN BOYD
. I am a watchman. On the 19th of July, about five o'clock in the morning, I was called to the prosecutor's house, and found the prisoner in the area. I told him to come up, and found the butter and mutton in his pocket.

HENRY HAWARD
. I am a private watchman. On the 19th of July, a little before five o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner go down York-buildings. I went home at five o'clock, heard the alarm, and found him in the area. I found a screw-driver and a hook in his pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1360.
JAMES HOY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , one watch, value 6s. , the property of
Thomas Wood
.

JOHN MURRAY
. I am servant to
Thomas Wood
, who is a pawnbroker , and lives in St. Giles's
. On the 27th of July, the prisoner pledged a watch for 4s. He came again in the evening, and I advanced him 2s. more on it. I put it on the counter by the side of the boy, while he made out the ticket. I went to the further end of the shop, to serve some other person; when I returned the prisoner was gone, and the watch also. About half-past eight o'clock he was stopped at Burrows's with it.

ROBERT EDWARDS
. I am a constable. I heard a noise in Burrows's shop, went in, and took the prisoner and watch. He wanted to escape.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The boy gave me the watch with the 2s., and being in distress, I did not tell him of his mistake.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1361.
WILLIAM GROVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , one watch, value 30s.; one seal, value 1s.; two watch-keys, value 6d., and one piece of ribbon, value 3d. , the goods of
Samuel Gwilliams
.

SAMUEL GWILLIAMS. On the 1st of August, about half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, when I came home, I found the prisoner in the house. I missed my watch, which I had left safe. As I was taking him before a magistrate, he told me if I took up two boys I should get my watch again. My wife was at home - She is ill.

JOHN BRANCH
. I live in Harford-place, Haggerston
-the prosecutor lives there also. I saw the prisoner come out of the prosecutor's house, with the watch in his hand; he ran off - I was very near him; the watch appeared white. Mr. Davis, the publican, took him. I do not know what he did with the watch.

JOHN WELLS
. I live at Haggerston. About three o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner sitting on a bench with two other boys, opposite the prosecutor's house - I was sitting on the same bench myself, but farther on. I afterwards saw the prisoner run out of the prosecutor's house with a silver watch in his hand. I called out Stop thief! and told Mr. Davis, he stopped him. Before he was stopped, he had passed the two boys who had been with him - They said they would run round and meet him; he was within a yard of them. I kept sight of him all the while, but do not know what was done with the watch.
SAMUEL GWILLIAMS re-examined. My watch was a silver one; it had a black ribbon, and was worth 30s.

WILLIAM HENRY WELLS
. I saw the prisoner sitting on a bench opposite the prosecutor's house, with some other boys. I saw him give the watch to two boys; he went round the corner of Davis's house, into a brick-field; Davis ran out, and took him there.
Q. What colour was the watch - A. White, with a black ribbon.
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1362.
DAVID GIBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , two gowns, value 11s. , the goods of
Eliza Pickman
, spinster .

ELIZA PICKMAN. I keep the Hampshire Hog, public-house, in Rosemary-lane
. On the 13th of August I saw the prisoner coming down stairs; I stopped him, and found the gowns in his apron, which were taken from my second-floor room.

JOHN BOUTLE
. I am a street-keeper. I took the prisoner in the passage. He said a man threw them down, and he picked them up.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 23.

Confined One Year , and
publicly Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1363.
HENRY GRAINGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of May , six loaves of bread, value 6s. , the property of
James Ward
.

ANN ELIZA WARD
. I am the wife of
James Ward
, who is a baker , and lives in York-street, Westminster, the prisoner was our servant . On the 29th of May, I sent him with thirty-six quarterns and fifty half-quartern loaves to Mr. Small, Knightsbridge. I always enter them in a book, which he took with him. On examining the book next morning, I found the thirty-six altered to thirty. Mrs. Small had given him a receipt for thirty loaves. I charged him with it, he denied it, but afterwards said he would pay for them if I would say nothing about it. I told him I would send for an officer when my husband came home-this was on Saturday; he left, and never returned till Sunday morning, when he came for his wages.
Prisoner. Q.Did you count the bread - A. Yes.

MARY SMALL
. I keep a chandler's shop at Knights-bridge. On the 29th of May the prisoner brought me fifty half-quartern loaves and only thirty quarterns. He entered them in my book as thirty.
Prisoner's Defence. I only took thirty.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1364.
THOMAS EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , one watch, value 15s; and six shirts, value 6s. , the goods of
Thomas Mercer
and
Ebenezer Burgess
.
The prosecutors not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1365.
WILLIAM INGRAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , five fathoms of rope, value 5s.; one spike-nail, value 1s., the property of the
East India Dock Company
; one grappling iron, value 2s., the property of
William Green
; 8s. in monies numbered, and one 1l. bank note , the property of
James Murdock
.
SECOND COUNT. the same, only stating the bank note and monies to be the property of the said East India Dock Company.

MR. JAMES MURDOCK. I am chief clerk in the East India Docks
. On Sunday, the 9th of August, at half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, I went into the Docks, which are enclosed by a wall twenty feet high. I went to the back door of the office, and unlocked it, but found I could not open it when it was unlocked. I looked through the glass of the door, and found a piece of wood placed under the lock, to prevent its being opened. The watchman, Holmes, got in - I then entered the office, and found a spike-nail by the door, which was not there at half-past eight o'clock that morning. Several of the desk locks were broken open, and a drawer, where I kept money, was forced open, and a 1l. note and 8s. taken out. Every thing was safe in the morning when I was there. The key of the door, which is always left inside, was taken out. I went to the lodge, where the iron chest is deposited, the sash of the window was closed. I found it had been forced, there were marks on the iron-chest, apparently, as if it had been attempted with a crow. I went up to the room above, and tried to force the door, but found it resisted. I called Holmes to force it. I went to get a ladder, returned, and found the prisoner in his custody; he had been a labourer in the Company's service for two years, and knew where the property was kept; I have paid him from the very drawer where the money was taken from. He was not in the Company's service at the time, and had no business in the Docks. A grappling-iron and a piece of rope were in the room where he was found, which was not the right place for them.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not see two men come into the Dock - A. I saw them leave it - They had no business there.

JOHN HOLMES
. I am a watchman. I went to the office. Mr. Murdock has spoken correctly. While he was gone for the ladder I forced the door open, and found the prisoner in the upper room, with the grappling iron and rope - He got up as if he was asleep. I found a chisel in the office.

ALEXANDER LIGHTERNESS
. I am superintendant of the Docks. I went to the lodge with Mr. Murdock-he has spoken correctly. I went to the upper room with Holmes, and found the prisoner getting off the floor; I asked him how he came there? he said he came in in the Lord Castlereagh, and got drunk, that he saw two men up there, and went up to them, but they swam away. I told him it was impossible for him to see that; he then said he did not see them swim across, but they said they were going to swim; that they beat him very much, and ran away. He did not appear to have been beat.

JOHN GOTTY
. I am a Thames Police officer. I took the prisoner into custody; I asked him how he got into the Docks? he said he got in at the Export Dock gate, and went on board the Lord Castlereagh, which laid in the basin, and passed into the Import Dock with her. I asked him if he had been employed on board the ship on Saturday? he said No. He said the window was open when he came there. I asked him who the two men were that he spoke of? He said there were no men, nor any person with him at all; that he told the people of the Dock that there was, but it was a lie,

THOMAS WATTS
. I am a carpenter in the Docks. The grappling-iron and spike-nail were in my care, at my bench, which was sixty yards from the lodge, the chisel was in my bench, which was broken open. I believe it has been used against a very hard substance; they are the property of the East India Dock Company.

WILLIAM SANDERS
. I found two keys in the cellar under the lodge, where the prisoner was found - He could have thrown them there.
MR. MURDOCK re-examined. They are the keys of the front office door and the book-case. I have never found the money.
Prisoner's Defence. I got drunk in the ship, went to sleep, awoke, and saw the people walking about the Dock.
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1366.
JAMES TURNER
and
JAMES PERKINS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , eight yards of cotton, value 9s. , the property of
Samuel Haskins
.

SAMUEL HASKINS
. I live at Shadwell
. The cotton hung outside my door. On the 6th of July, about eight o'clock in the evening, Harris called me, and I missed it; the prisoners were brought back with it.

EMANUEL HARRIS
. I am a slopseller, and live opposite to the prosecutor. I was at my door, and saw the prisoners, with another man, come up to his door, and halfway by the window, they returned back, and the prisoners went up the steps next door, the other went intothe next shop. Perkins took the cotton off the prosecutor's iron rail, and put it under Turner's smock-frock - They went away together. Turner walked before, the other man came out, and walked with Perkins; I told Haskins, pursued them, and took Turner about twenty doors off - I took the cotton from under his frock. Next day Perkins came by the door with another man, and pointed over to the house. I took him, and am certain he is the man.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
TURNER'S Defence. I know nothing of it.
PERKINS'S Defence. I know nothing of it.

PERKINS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

TURNER -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1367.
WILLIAM HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April , eight brass plated shade mounts, value 4s. , the property of
Josiah Spode
and
William Copeland
.

WILLIAM DUNN
. I am a manufacturer of plated articles for Spode and Copeland, and live in Swallow-street. On the 4th of April I sent sixty-four shade mounts to them(looking at eight). I know these are part of the lot; other people always pack them sixteen in a lot, these were packed eight in a lot,

BARNARD STONE
. I am servant to Mr. Dunn. I delivered eight parcels of mounts to Mr. Powell, at the prosecutors' warehouse, in Portugal-street.

WILLIAM VALENTINE POWELL
. I am servant to Messrs. Josiah Spode and William Copeland. On Saturday, the 4th of April, I received eight parcels of mounts from Stone-on the Monday following I missed one parcel. The prisoner was a stranger.

JOHN DAWSON
. I work for Mr. Dunn. I made the brass shade mounts produced; on the 10th of July I saw them at Mr. Thacker's, in Blackfriars-road, exposed for sale - I knew them again; having heard they were missed, I told Mr. Dunn. Potter and I went and gave Thacker 7s. for them, the prime cost is 24s.

CHARLES THACKER
. I am a broker, and live in Blackfriars-road. I bought the mounts at Mr. Bullock's auction, in Holborn.

EDWARD BULLOCK
. I am an auctioneer. The shade mounts were sent to my sale by
George Want
.

GEORGE WANT
. I received them from Lock, and sent them the next day to Bullock for sale.

JAMES LOCK
. I am a broker, and live in Exeter-street; the prisoner sold me a duplicate of the mounts produced, I have known him for two years. My servant redeemed them at Townsend's.

WILLIAM DUTTON
TOWNSEND. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Little Russell-street, Covent Garden. On the 6th of April, the prisoner pledged them with me in the name of
John Cooper
; he said his brother made them for ball or assembly-rooms.

PETER PERRY
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner in July - He said he bought the duplicate of a man, and sold it to Lock. I afterwards took him to Townsend, he recognised him as the man who pledged them; the prisoner did not deny it.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the duplicate of a man in Spring Gardens for 1s. I could not find him again.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Common Sergeant.

1368.
SOPHIA COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , one scarf, value 6s.; one shawl, value 6s.; one pair of stocking, value 3s., and one whittle, value 9s. , the goods of
Charles Wright
.

CHARLES WRIGHT. A am a dyer , and live in Wellington-place, Goswell-street
; the prisoner is my wife's sister. I took her into my house as a servant . On the 9th of July, when I got up in the morning, I missed her and the property; she had given me no notice. I found her in George-street, Hampstead-road, about three hours afterwards. I found the shawl on her back, which had been left with me to dye.
Prisoner. Q. What wages did you give me - A.I promised to give her what she deserved; I took her in out of compassion.
(Shawl sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. My sister gave me the things.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1369.
ANN ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , eight shillings and two sixpences , the monies of
John Thomas
.

JOHN THOMAS
. I live in James-street, Manchester-square
. On the 16th of July, about six o'clock in the morning, I awoke and saw the prisoner at my bed-room table taking my money, which I had put there the night before; my door was not locked. She ran away - I ran down, but she got out. I returned and dressed myself, ran out, and overtook her in Wellbeck-street; I took her to the watch-house. She said she would give me the money if I would let her go. I found it in her hand.

WILLIAM NEWITT
. The prisoner was given into my charge. She gave me 8s. from under her cloak, and begged forgiveness.
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Confined Two Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1370.
ROBERT ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September . one shawl, value 10s., the goods of
Susan Jenkins
, spinster , from her person .

SUSAN JENKINS. I live at John's-hill, Ratcliff-highway. On the 13th of September, about nine o'clock at night, I was coming by the Dock wall
with Mr. and Mrs. Williams, aman snatched off my shawl, and ran up Dock-street. I could not see who did it; the prisoner was stopped in about five minutes. I took up the shawl in the crowd.

WILLIAM TALBOT
. I am a boot-maker. I was returning home, and saw the prisoner walking in the road in company with another man, who was behind the prosecutrix; the prisoner came on the pavement. I watched them, his companion kept behind him to hide him from my view. I saw him lift up the shawl to see if it was fastened. At the corner of Dock-street he snatched itoff, and ran up Dock-street. I pursued, calling out "Stop thief!" I never lost sight of him till he was taken - He dropped the shawl. He said it was only a joke.

NATHANIEL NATHAN
. I am a constable. I heard the alarm, and followed the prisoner up Dock-street. I took him to the office; he said he only did it out of a lark.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to meet a young woman; I mistook the prosecutrix for her, and took her shawl in a joke.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1371.
ALICE TAYLOR
was indicted, for
that she, on the 16th of July , feloniously and maliciously, by fraud, did take and carry away a certain male child, called
Thomas Hall
, under the age of ten years (to wit) about the age of ten months, with intent to deprive
Hannah Hall
, the mother of the said child , of the possession of it, by concealing and detaining it from its said mother, against the statute .
SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating her intent to be to deprive one Hannah Hall, a person having the lawful care and charge of the said child, of the possession of it.

HANNAH HALL. I live at Mr. Fairfax's. in Hosier-lane, and sell fruit in the street . On the 9th of July, I was selling fruit near the Horse Guards. The prisoner came up to me with a little girl about seven years old - She asked the price of my fruit, and then asked if my name was Lindsay; I said, No. She said she knew a poor woman of that name whom she wished to employ, and asked if I went out to work. I said I was glad to do any thing; my child was in my arms, his name is Thomas - He was then nine months old. She then took me to a cook-shop, and treated me with a dinner; she and the little girl eat with me. While we were in the shop, she asked me to fetch her a bundle from Mr. Smith's, No. 35, Oakley-street, Lambeth; she gave me 1s. to go, and said she would take care of my child while I was gone. I left my child with her in the cook-shop, which was near the Horse Guards. I went to No. 35, Oakley-street - I could find no such person, nor could I hear any thing of the prisoner. I returned to the cook-shop, the prisoner and my child were both gone.

Q. Did the girl, who was with the prisoner, appear sensible - A. Yes; I had bills printed, describing my child and the prisoner, and made my loss as public as possible. I heard nothing of it till about two months after; when Mr. Betts took me to Aylesbury prison, where I saw the prisoner with three others; I immediately knew her to be the woman. I afterwards saw my child with six more children, about the same age, and knew my own immediately. Mr. Betts brought the girl to town with him, who was with the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not find your child better dressed and better fed, than when it was with you - A. Yes; I found by the neighbours that she had behaved very well to it-this is the child which I have in my arms.

JOHN LEGATE. I am a waiter at a cook-shop at Charing-cross. I remember the prosecutrix being there with a woman and little a girl, she had the child in her arms. She afterwards returned and complained of losing her child - I cannot swear to the woman.

THOMAS FAIRFAX
. I keep the Horse and Groom, public-house, in Hosier-lane, the prosecutrix lodges with me. On the 9th of July, she went out with her child, and returned at night without it; she was crying, and appeared greatly distressed.

JOSEPH WHITE
. I live in Vine-street, Lambeth, the prisoner is a relation of my wife's. In July last, she came to my house with the child present, and a little girl about nine years old. She said the child was her own-It appeared to be eight or nine months old. She remained at my house about a fortnight.
Q. Who was the little girl - A. The child of a relation of her's, who lived with her. She left my house to go into the country, and was very kind to the child.

THOMAS SAWYER BETTS
. I am overseer of the parish of Wootton; the prisoner lived there with her husband, who is a bricklayer - They never had a child. In July last, she came to Wootton with a child about eight or nine months old; in consequence of an advertisement, I went to her about the child. She said it was her's, and that she was delivered of it on the 7th of July; she said she was taken unwell in her journey to town, and when she got to town, she was delivered of it. I knew her before, and understood that she was pregnant before she left. I took the little girl, who lived with her, to Mrs. Hall, in town; I then took Mrs. Hall to Wootton, and showed her the child in Aylesbury gaol. I showed her the child with six others, and she immediately knew her own.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been married twenty-three years, and have a good character. I did not take the child with intent to steal it; I treated it very kind, and meant to return it to its mother.
GUILTY . Aged 43.
Confined Six Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1372.
DANIEL PAGE
and
WILLIAM TURNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 150lbs. of lead, value 18s., the goods of
Eleanor Moultrie
, widow , and fixed to her dwelling-house .

SIMON WELLS
. I am a watchman of Marylebone, my beat is in Norton-street. The prosecutrix's house is No. 67, Portland-street
. On the 11th of July, a little after one o'clock at night, I saw the prisoners pass my box - They had nothing with them then. My box is at the corner of Clipstone-street, next to Portland-street. As soon as they had got round my box, two other boys passed - I immediately went round to watch them, as I knew Page before. I lost them all in a moment. I listened sometime, and then heard a talking in the prosecutrix's yard, which is only fenced off by an hedge. I remained there till half-past one o'clock, then went round part of my beat, and returned and listened sometime. I heard something come down heavily, as if somebody had jumped down into the garden - I heard nothing more for sometime. I wentround my beat and called two o'clock; returned, and heard persons talking in the yard. Nobody came out. I waited there, and omitted to call the half-hour, as I thought they might have seen me. I called the hour of three up Carburton-street, and the middle of Norton-street, and returned without finishing my round. When I came to the corner of Carburton-street, I saw two persons come in a direction from the prosecutrix's premises; they were about twenty yards from the house. I drew back and concealed myself, that they might not see me. They came up and passed me; they were each loaded. I followed and asked them what they had? they said Nothing; I desired them to stop and let me see, and laid hold of Turner; he dropped a piece of lead at my feet, which was rolled up. He had another piece and ran away with it. I had taken Page and kept him. I sprung my rattle. Turner was stopped in about five minutes. I am certain he is the man. I found two pieces of lead on Page also, rolled up under his coat. I took them both to the watch-house. I went to the prosecutrix's house that day, and took one piece of lead. I found the balcony partly stripped of its lead. The lead fitted; it appeared fresh cut. I found a knife on Page, which appeared to have cut lead.

Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. The transaction began about one o'clock-Yes. I waited there till three o'clock. I am sure they are the men who passed my box. I stopped them in Cirencester-place, which is two hundred yards from the house. I saw the lead dropped.

THOMAS FORBES KELSALL
. I am Mrs. Elizabeth Moultrie's grandson. She keeps a house in the parish of Marylebone, and is a widow. The lead was safe the day before the prisoners were taken. The next morning I found it was stolen.

JOHN MONTEITH
. I am a patrol. The prosecutor's house is within my district. I herd the alarm, and took Turner. I saw Moody stop him in Cleveland-street. I found one piece of lead upon him, and another piece in the way he came. I saw him throw it away.

JOHN MOODY
. I am a watchman. I heard the rattle sprung at the corner of Cleveland-street, and saw Wells struggling with the prisoners. Turner got from him, and I took him.

THOMAS LESTER
. I am a labourer to the East India Company, and live in Charlton-street. I heard the rattle sprung, looked out of the window, and saw two men running, and the watchman pursuing them. I saw the watchman take one of the prisoners. Soon after I saw a third man come up the street, with his hands in his pockets, as if he had something heavy in them. I saw him go towards Mr. Morris's house.

JOHN ANNIS
. I am a plumber. I went to the prosecutrix's premises, and found a great deal of lead cut away, part of it was torn, and part cut. I saw a part of it compared with the balcony, it fitted. The four pieces weighed 130lbs.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you swear the lead was cut from that place - A. Yes. I repaired it; It appeared fresh cut. The balcony joins the dwelling-house.

THOMAS KNIGHT
. I am a carpenter. I saw the balcony the morning it was stripped. About two feet and a quarter of lead was cut away.
EDWARD CHAMBERLAIN. I was constable of the night. The prisoners and the lead were brought to the watchhouse, and two knives. I found a knife on Turner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
PAGE'S Defence. The man never saw me before.

PAGE -
GUILTY . Aged 29.

TURNER -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1373.
CHARLES ALLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , one coat, value 9s. ; the goods of
Francis Darnell
.

FRANCIS DARNELL. I am a hackney coachman . On the 16th of September I put my coat in the coach, in Colchester-street, Whitechapel
.

JAMES BENTLEY
. I had just washed the coach, and saw the prisoner put his hand into it, take the coat out, and run away. I pursued and brought him back with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1374.
RICHARD GERRING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 49lbs. of fat, value 25s. , the goods of
John Jackson
.
SECOND COUNT, the same, only stating it to be the property of some person or persons unknown.

JOHN JACKSON. I am master of a slaughter-house in Marshall-street, Carnaby-market
. On the 24th of July I slaughtered twelve oxen, and hung them up in the slaughter-house. The prisoner had formerly been employed to work there. Next morning, about ten o'clock, I was going along Broad-street, opposite my slaughter-house gate, and saw him. He crossed over the way from me. He had a cloth on his shoulder. I saw some fat in it through a hole. It was in a butcher's round frock; the arms were tied up, to make it serve for a bag. I followed him up Poland-street; he went into Dring's melting-house, in Wardour-street. I then went into Mr. Dring's shop, in Oxford-street, and told his servant my suspicions. He took me to the melting-house, and showed me the fat which they said the prisoner had brought; from its appearance I knew it was stolen. It consisted of what we call toungs and shoulders of tripe, which is never cut away with the fat, it being always sold with the tripe. There was also about 21lbs. which had been taken in a hot state from the internal part of the bullock. Some pieces had the entrails on them. It was not cleaned in the usual way for sale. I got an officer, took him to Dring's shop, and found the prisoner there, with a note to receive his money for the fat. I gave him in charge to Plank, who asked him how he came by the fat. He said it was his own property; that he bought it and paid for it. He said he would not go without his money. Plank took him into custody. As we were going along, he said he would tell me where he got the fat; that he had it of two men, who were sitting at the Maidenhead public-house, New-street, close by. Plank and I went there, and found two men who worked for me. They denied it, and the magistrate discharged them; they promised to appear at the next examination, which one did, and the other absconded.

SAMUEL PLANK
