. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner at Dring's; he said he bought the fat. I asked him where, he refused to tell me. As I was taking him to the office, he said he received it of two men, who were at the Maidenhead, and that the prosecutor knew them. I found two of the prosecutor's men there and took them to the prisoner, who said they were the men. They were all three examined before the magistrate. The prisoner then denied that they were the men, or that he had said so.

REDIT FRESSINGFIELD
. I am a servant at Dring's melting-house, in Wardour-street. On the 25th of July, about ten o'clock in the morning, the prisoner brought two parcels of fat at two different times, which weighed six stone. I gave him an order to receive the money for it at the shop. I showed the fat to Jackson in the same state as he had brought it.

WILLIAM HEIDENMARK
. I am the prosecutor's servant. I get up at two o'clock to work. I went to breakfast with Bailey at the public-house; the prisoner came in; Bailey said, "There is a parcel left for you, up in the corner." The prisoner took it up; he did not say who left it. I do not know what it was, or who brought it in. Bailey helped him up with it. He has since run away. I do not know what colour it was, or any thing about it.
SAMUEL PLANK re-examined. It was with great difficulty I could get the last witness to attend before the Grand Jury, or to be examined before the magistrate.
Prisoner's Defence. I had agreed to call for it at the public-house. I was taken, and told them two men gave it to me. The officer took the wrong two men.
GUILTY . Aged 74.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1375.
GEORGE GILLAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of June , one shirt, value 5s. , the goods of
William Thomas
.

WILLIAM THOMAS
. I live at Chelsea
; my wife is a laundress. She said the prisoner had taken a shirt; I ran out, stopped him, and found it in his jacket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Poverty induced me to do it.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Three Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1376.
MARY WOODWARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , one scarf, value 7s.; one gown, value 6s.; two handkerchiefs, value 2s.; four books, value 4s.; one petticoat, value 1s.; five stockings, value 2s.; one apron, value 1s.; and one ridicule, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Abbott
.
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1377.
SAMUEL VAUGHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , one watch, value 25s. , the goods of
Joseph Bacon
.

ANN BACON
. I am the mother of
Joseph Bacon
, and live in Great Bath-street, Coldbath-square
. On the 8th of September, between six and seven o'clock at night, the prisoner came and said a person wanted my daughter, who does not live at home. I told him where to find her. I turned my back to go to the drawers while the prisoner was there. Soon after he was gone I missed the watch off the mantle-piece.

JOHN FORBES
. I am a constable. I met the prisoner in Charter-house-lane, with two others. The prisoner left them and ran off. I secured him, and found the watch concealed in his shirt.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1378.
JAMES REAVELY
and
EDWARD MANSFIELD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 14lbs. of lead, value 4s., and one brass cock, value 2s. the goods of
Ann Garnes
, widow , and fixed to her dwelling-house .

ANN GARNES
. I am not a widow.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1379.
JAMES REAVELY
and
EDWARD MANSFIELD
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 4lbs. of lead, value 1s., and one brass cock, value 2s., belonging to
William Tankard
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .

WILLIAM TANKARD
. I live at No. 1, Dean's-place, Somers'-town, St. Pancras
, and keep the house. On the 26th of June, in the morning, I lost a brass cock and a piece of leaden pipe, which were fixed to my dwelling-house.

JOHN DEAN
. I am watchman of Mornington-place. On the 26th of June, between four and five o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoners go up Mr. Rhodes's field, with a bundle in their hands, which they put into a ditch, and then got into the ditch themselves. Pretlove and I went and took them. They said they had found a prize. There was a bundle of wet linen, some lead, and a brass cock laid between them. I saw them shift the bundles from one to the other, as they appeared heavy.

DAVID PRETLOVE. I am a watchman. I went with Dean, and found the prisoners in a ditch, One of them had his breeches down; just opposite to him was a quantity of leaden pipe. I tied up the lead. I turned aside, saw the bundle of linen, and took them to the watchhouse.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
REAVELY'S Defence. I was going to bathe, and found the lead in a ditch.

REARLY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

MANSFIELD -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1380.
JAMES RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , one watch, value 6l.; two seals, value 6d., and two keys, value 6d., the property of
John Everleigh
, from his person .

JOHN EVERLEIGH
. On the 24th of July, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was going through the posts on Saffron-hill
, and saw some men standing there; they divided; as I came to the posts the prisoner rushed against me with great violence, and put his hands to my fob. I felt him draw my watch out, and immediately secured him; the others closed upon me. I took the watch from him. The gang demanded of me to let him go. I refused and held him fast. I had another person with me, or they would have rescued him. They wanted me to take him into a house to search him. I held him about ten minutes, when Limbrick and Read came and took him. I never let him go.
JOHN LIMBRICK. I am an officer. Read and I were going by, and took the prisoner in charge from the prosecutor.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor was in liquor, and said I took his watch. I know nothing about it.
GUILTY Aged 18.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1381.
RICHARD RUFFEN
and
GEORGE BOYCE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , one handkerchief, value 5s., the property of the Rev.
Charles Cecil Bates
, Clerk, from his person .

THOMAS WESTBROOK. I am a labourer. On the 20th of June, I was standing opposite the hustings, in Covent-garden
, and saw the prisoners in company. Boyce took a silk handkerchief out of Mr. Bates's pocket, and gave it to Ruffen. I told him of it, and pointed the prisoners out to the prosecutor; he took one, and I took the other to Bow-street - He gave them in charge to an officer, who found the handkerchief in Ruffen's breeches. I had seen them in company before. The prosecutor attended before the magistrate, and swore to the handkerchief in the presence of the prisoners, they said nothing to it. I know the prosecutor's name is
Charles Cecil Bates
.

WILLIAM WESTCOAT. I am an officer. The prisoners were brought to me by Westbrook and Mr. Bates, who gave them in charge. I searched them, and found one handkerchief in Ruffen's hat, and another in his breeches, which the prosecutor claimed - I produce it.

RUFFEN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BOYCE -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1382.
ELIZA RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , one shawl, value 2s., and one bonnet, value 1s. , the goods of
John Byrne
.

SUSAN BYRNE
. I am the wife of
John Byrne
, we live in Clement's-lane, Strand
. On the 20th of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner come out of my room with my bonnet and shawl; I followed her into the next passage, and asked her what she had got? she said it was nothing to me. I found my shawl and bonnet under her own shawl, and gave her in charge.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I took the prisoner in charge - She was intoxicated, and said if she did take it she did not know it. (Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined One Month .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1383.
JOHN MAINWARING
was indicted for
stealing 36 caps, value 2l. 5s. , the goods of
Stephen Pige
.

STEPHEN PIGE. I am a furrier . The prisoner was my servant . He went out with thirty-six caps to sell for me he never paid me the money, but absconded. I expected to receive the money, but not to see the caps again.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1384.
JOHN MORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , two firkins, value 2s., and 10 gallons of lamp-black, value 14s. , the goods of
William Francis
.

HENRY COLLINGTON. I am shopman to Mr.
William Francis
, who is an oilman and lives, in Long-acre, and has a warehouse in Mercer-street
, the prisoner was his porter . The keys of the warehouse hung in the counting-house. I missed them about eight o'clock in the morning of the 27th of June, went to the warehouse, and saw the prisoner come down with two firkins of lamp-black under his arm. I watched him into Short's-gardens - He took them into a house belonging to one Hambleton. I met two officers, who went with me, and took him and the lampblack.
RICHARD ROW WICKS. I am an officer. I took the prisoner and lamp-black at an old iron-shop in Short's-gardens; he said he took it from his master's warehouse.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. My mistress told me to take it to Soho-square. I left it in Short's-gardens while I got my breakfast.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1385.
SARAH MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , one watch, value 20s. , the goods of
Robert Johnson
.
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1386.
FRANCIS JORDAN
and
GEORGE RICE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , from the person of
William Stewart
, one shirt, value 6s.; one handkerchief, value 3s.; a 1l. bank note, and the sum of 2l. 2s. in monies, numbered , his property.

WILLIAM STEWART
. I am a sailor . On the 7th of August, I was in company with the prisoners. I went to bed about two o'clock in the morning, I awoke in about ten minutes, and saw them feeling in my pocket; they put out the light, and ran down stairs. They were taken next day. The property was never found.

PETER PETERSON
. I am a watchman. I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoners running, I took Jordan; Rice got away - He was taken next day. Nothing was found on them.

RICE'S Defence. He was drunk. I never touched his clothes.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1387.
JOHN EDWARDS
and
BENJAMIN PARR
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of July , one handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Joseph Wells
, from his person .

WILLIAM KERBY
. I am a servant at Fairman's library, in Bond-street
. I was standing at the door on the 23d of July, and saw Joseph Wells, the prosecutor, go by, I knew him very well before; the prisoners were following him. I went out and saw Edwards take the handkerchief out of his pocket, and give it to Parr - I seized them both; another man who was with them ran away. Edwards got from me, and ran off - He was stopped; Parr pulled the handkerchief from his bosom, and threw it down. I know the prosecutor's name is
Joseph Wells
.
EDWARDS'S Defence. I know nothing of it.
PARR'S Defence. The prosecutor has compounded felony, he took 13s. not to appear against us.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

PARR -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1388.
ANN DOWSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , sixteen yards of ribbon, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Herbert
.

THOMAS HERBERT. I am an haberdasher , and live in the City-road
. On the 14th of September, the prisoner came to the shop for some Waterloo blue-ribbon; I shewed her several drawers, and while my servant was reaching some others, I saw her put a piece under her apron. I took it from her; she said she had taken it up to look at.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 14.

Judgment respited
.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1389.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of June , one curtain-pin, value 5s. , the goods of
David Conly
, the elder, and
David Conly
, the younger.

DAVID CONLY
, JUN. I am in partnership with my father, whose name is David, we are upholsterers
, and live in Ratcliff-highway
. On the 22d of June, Langdale pointed the prisoner out me. I missed a pin from the window; I collared him, and found it under his jacket.
SAMPSON LANGDALE. I live opposite to the prosecutors'. I saw the prisoner go in and take something out of the window, and put it under his jacket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress.
GUILTY . Aged 67.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1390.
JAMES BATES
was indicted, for
stealing, on the 4th of September , twenty-eight yards of cotton, value 1l. 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Garner
.

MARY ANN WEAVER
. On the 4th of September, about half-past nine o'clock at night, I was in Long-acre
, and saw the prisoner lurking about the prosecutor's shop, he went backward and forward, several times; he went up to the door, and took the print off the rail inside the shop door, and ran over into Bow-street. I went and informed the prosecutor - we went in pursuit of him; I knew the prisoner before, we took him in White Hart-yard. I pointed him out to the shopman there. The property was not found.

HENRY ENGLISH
. I am shopman to Mr. Thomas Garner. Weaver informed me the print was taken, I immediately missed it. She went with me - We found the prisoner in White Hart-yard coming out of his house; he denied having been in Long-acre that evening, and said his name was not Bates. He broke from me-the watchman took him.
Prisoner's Defence. I can prove where I was at the time.

LOUISA HALL
. I live in the prisoner's father's house in White Hart-yard, he was at home from eight to ten o'clock, and had not been out three minutes before he was taken.
Q. How far is Long-acre from the house - A. Not far; the prisoner's father deals in old stores.

-HAWELL. The witness, Weaver, works with me in Drury-lane. I heard her say she did not see the prisoner take the cotton, for it was taken while she went in to tell the shopman that there was a suspicious character at the door.

ANN PRITCHARD
. I work with Weaver. She said she did not see the prisoner take the print.

MARY BURROWS
. I heard her say she did not see the prisoner take it.

MARY ANN
WEAVER. The witnesses work in the same room with me; I never said any such words.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1391.
RICHARD BRIGENSHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , one book, value 3s. , the goods of
Francis Claridge
.
The prosecutor not appearing, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.
